sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Janet John)
articles.description: Useful Figma plugins that will help you fix all the little slowdowns and boost your productivity. From color management and image assets to SVG shapes and animation. That‚Äôs our new guide to Figma.
articles.title: Useful Figma Plugins And Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris Lje≈°njanin)
articles.description: How do we build and establish a successful, bulletproof design system? What‚Äôs the state of HTML Email? And what are new, smart interface design patterns we could use? Let‚Äôs find out. With our [brand new online workshops](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/) on front-end & design ‚Äî to help us all boost skills online.
articles.title: New Smashing Workshops on Front-End & Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Don)
articles.description: Often you need two different sets of navigation stacks for pre and post user authentication. Usually, to see more content, you have to be authenticated in some way. Let‚Äôs look at how to mount and unmount navigation stack based on a met condition in React Native.
articles.title: Handling Mounting And Unmounting Of Navigation Routes In React Native

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Henrik Fricke)
articles.description: Embedding code examples with third-party scripts often leads to tracking or cookies. We always wanted to have a simple website with a good UX, so setting cookies for no reason wasn‚Äôt an option for us. Now, with Indiepen, we are proud to introduce a privacy-friendly alternative.
articles.title: Cookieless Alternative To Embed HTML, CSS And JS Code Snippets

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we‚Äôre talking about designing for safety. What does it mean to consider vulnerable users in our designs? Drew McLellan talks to expert Eva PenzeyMoog to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 41 With Eva PenzeyMoog: Designing For Safety

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: What exactly is HTTP/3? Why was it needed so soon after HTTP/2 (which was only finalized in 2015)? How can or should you use it? And especially, how does this improve web performance? Let‚Äôs find out.
articles.title: HTTP/3 From A To Z: Core Concepts (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: VS Code can be supercharged wuth hundreds of [VS Code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/). In this article, Leonardo shares four useful extensions that help him in his daily work.
articles.title: Four Useful VSCode Extensions For Web Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Let‚Äôs find out.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Arihant Verma)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.
articles.title: React Children And Iteration Methods

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.
articles.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, you‚Äôll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units aren‚Äôt so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alexander Dubovoy)
articles.description: Next.js has strong opinions about how to organize JavaScript but not CSS. How can we develop patterns that encourage best CSS practices while also following the framework‚Äôs logic? The answer is surprisingly simple ‚Äî to write well-structured CSS that balances global and local styling concerns.
articles.title: Global vs. Local Styling In Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: Gatsby recently announced the launch of ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù. In this article, Paul Scanlon explains how to get the current location of the International Space Station (ISS) as it orbits the Earth in real-time using [Gatsby Functions](https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/reference/functions/) and then display it on a 3D interactive globe using [React Three Fibre](https://github.com/pmndrs/react-three-fiber).
articles.title: Gatsby Serverless Functions And The International Space Station

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Many web design agencies consider it a badge of honor that they win work exclusively through word-of-mouth recommendations. In this article, Paul Boag explains why that is entirely the wrong attitude and what to do about it.
articles.title: A Guide To Attracting Clients To Your Agency

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Matthew Talebi)
articles.description: Are you running a business and have too many things going on at once? Meetings, bugs, customer feedback, new clients in addition to your already tight deadlines? Let‚Äôs face it, time management is hard, and it becomes even more difficult in the trying times we are in.
articles.title: Adding Time To Your Schedule As A Professional

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? We‚Äôve collected some useful color tools and resources that we‚Äôve discovered lately ‚Äî to help you get the most out of your creativity. We‚Äôve also just recently covered [CSS auditing tools](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-auditing-tools/), [CSS generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/css-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/), [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) and [VS code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/) ‚Äî you might find them useful, too.
articles.title: Color Tools And Resources

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alba Silvente)

In addition to a step-by-step guide on how to migrate WordPress to Storyblok Headless CMS, the problems that will arise during the process and how to deal with them.

articles.description: By adding visual elements to your tests, you can gain more options to add meaningful ways in maintaining a high level of quality for your app. Colby Fayock explains how.
articles.title: Maintaining End-To-End Quality With Visual Testing

articles.title: Three Insights I Gained While Researching Vue.js Accessibility

articles.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?

articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Broken Filters

articles.description: There are many benefits to coding in an online IDE or code editor. With these tools you don't need to set anything up locally, you can easily share your work, and they are often free to use. In this article, you'll learn what a code editor and an IDE are.

django-infinite-scroll

python manage.py startapp blog

articles.author: Mrinal Wadhwa
articles.description:
/ 
        ockam
      
    
Ockam is a rust library that makes it simple for distributed applications to guarantee end-to-end integrity, authenticity, and confidentiality of data.
In this post, we'll create two small Rust programs called Alice and Bob. Alice and Bob will send each other messages, over the network, via a cloud service. They will mutually authenticate each other and will have a cryptographic guarantee that en-route messages were not tampered or forged.
The intermediary cloud service and attackers on the network will not be able to see or change the contents of en-route messages. In later examples we'll also see how we can have this end-to-end protection even when the communication path between Alice and Bob is more complex - with multiple transport connections, a variety of‚Ä¶
articles.title: Build End-to-End Encryption in 51 lines of Rust

articles.author: borislav nikolov
articles.description:
I used only the tty (no X installed) for 5 nights. It was relaxing, and now I go back to it every time I am overwhelmed. 
I have to seriously re-think the way I spend time on my
BTW, browsing was actually way better than I thought, between eww, w3m, lynx, links2 and links2 -g, and sometimes just reading the html dump, I was able to navigate the modern web with reasonable success.
I bought used t440p laptop, they go from 100 to 300E. Super sturdy machine, like the opposite of my xps. Very easy to open, and very hackable.
Install debian and do some basic fixes to make the tty usable.
rate (whoa slow keyboard rate pisses me off)
add 'kbdrate -r 30 -d 0' to /etc/rc.local
ctrl+/ etc
super annoying that ctrl+/ sends Delete and I want to bind it to undo, to do that you have to:
$ showkeys

press ‚Ä¶
articles.title: tty only

articles.author: Gracie Gregory (she/her)
articles.description:
I don't know about you, but I frequently find myself lost in TikTok's #techtok content. There are so many brilliant content creators and software developers there sharing clips of their skills, inner monologues, humor, and beyond. Who knew that so much could be communicated and captured in just a few seconds? ü§Ø 
I also wanted to let you know that, whether you're on TikTok or not, there's an awesome opportunity to be featured on the CodeLand 2021 program using your skills and personality as a developer...
CodeLand Recess is a community-sourced track of short TikTok-style videos that will lend some fun, humor, and developer-realness to the day's events. We'd love to see a video submission from you! 
All CodeLand Recess video submissions are due by August 20th by 11:59 PM PT (6 AM UTC the following day). Get yours in soon! Instructions and examples here. 
CodeLand Recess!
articles.title: Are you on TikTok?

articles.author: Jan Dalheimer
articles.description:
Security breaches, leaks, and other attacks feature in the news almost weekly, often as the result of insecure systems. While it will always be an arms race between attackers and ‚Äúdefenders‚Äù, there is actually a lot that can be done by any developer to significantly decrease the risk of being the next successful target.
A couple of weeks ago Coop, one of Sweden‚Äôs largest grocery store chains, along with many other retailers in both Sweden and other countries, was hit by a large ransomware attack that effectively shut down entire stores for several days. Currently in the news is the Pegasus Project, which has uncovered espionage against presidents, journalists, human rights activists, and others using vulnerabilities in iMessage.
But not only people and organizations with large targets on t‚Ä¶
articles.title: Developing secure systems (Part 1): Why it matters

articles.author: Scott Hintze
articles.description:
Keyboard Shortcuts



  
  
  Hold Down Alt when Selecting Text


Let‚Äôs say you have a list of variables and you decide to change the scope from public to protected. You could use find and replace on the selected text, or you could just copy/paste over each modifier. Another option is block selecting. Holding down the Alt key while selecting allows you to include multiple lines to the position of the cursor rather than the entire line. The result is that when you type, cut or paste, it applies to every line selected. You could select all the public modifiers and simply type or paste protected to edit them all at once.

Cut and paste? What is so special about these? In Visual Studio. If you have nothing selected, the cut command will cut the entire line and paste will insert the entire line‚Ä¶
articles.title: Supercharge Your Coding in Visual Studio
